sentences: George Alan O'Dowd (born 14 June 1961), known professionally as Boy George, is an English singer, songwriter, disc jockey, fashion designer, photographer and record producer.
At the height of the band's fame, during the 1980s, they recorded global hit songs such as "Karma Chameleon", "Do You Really Want to Hurt Me" and "Time (Clock of the Heart)".
He was the lead singer of Jesus Loves You between 1989 and 1992.
In 2015, Boy George received an Ivor Novello Award from the British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors for Outstanding Services to British Music.
In 2002, he was voted 46th in a BBC poll of the 100 Greatest Britons.

Boy George was born George Alan O'Dowd at Barnehurst Hospital, Kent, England, on 14 June 1961 and raised in Woolwich, the second of five children born to builder Jerry O'Dowd (born Jeremiah; 1932–2004) and Dinah O'Dowd (born Christina Glynn; 1939).

It became Christmas number one and the best-selling single of 1984 in the United Kingdom.
Unlike many of the bands featured on the single, Culture Club did not perform at Live Aid in July 1985.
In 1986, George performed a guest-starring cameo role in an episode of the television series The A-Team titled "Cowboy George".
Also in 1986, Culture Club released their fourth album, From Luxury to Heartache (UK No. 10, US No. 32) which featured the hit single, "Move Away".
In July 1998, a reunited Culture Club performed three dates in Monte Carlo and then joined the Human League and Howard Jones in a "Big Rewind" tour of the US.
A new Culture Club album, Don't Mind If I Do, was released in 1999.
In 2006, the band decided to again reunite and tour, but George declined to join them.

On 20 May 2014, it was announced on Culture Club's official Facebook page the band were back together.
The band were scheduled to perform dates in America in 2014 before the UK tour in December.
The band was scheduled to tour New Zealand in 2016.

After the dissolution of Culture Club in 1986, Boy George entered treatment and was prescribed narcotics to treat his addiction to heroin.
In 1987, George released his first solo album, Sold, which garnered success in Europe.
Tense Nervous Headache (1988) and Boyfriend (1989) would be his next two internationally released albums; however, these two albums would not be distributed in the US.

Instead, Virgin Records selected several songs from each of these albums for a North American-only release called High Hat (1989).

In accepting the award for Best British Group from Boy George at the 1989 Brit Awards held at the Royal Albert Hall in London, Andy Bell of Erasure kissed George on stage to cheers from the crowd, with Bell stating it was an act in protest against Section 28.
In 1989, George formed his own record label, More Protein, and began recording under the name Jesus Loves You, writing under the pseudonym Angela Dust, a word play on angel dust.
He released several underground hits in the early 1990s; "After the Love", "Generations of Love" and "Bow Down Mister", the last giving him a UK Top 30 hit in 1991.

George released the rock-driven album Cheapness and Beauty in 1995.
